review: What is most admirable in this excellent film is how Heineman risks his life in the middle of the crossfire with his camera so that he can show us this tragic, appalling and complex situation to which there seems to be no solution and where one step forward means two steps back.
My favorite doc from True/False. This doc has many layers & is quite eye opening about the cartels, government, & people of Mexico.
A movie that just presents some realities to us without giving us any inclination as to how this tragic situation can ever be resolved.

This is an eye opening documentary which follows groups of vigilante's who are so fed up with Mexican drug cartels they have decided to do something about it. The problem is that the lines are blurred as to who the criminals are and on what side they are on. Watching this film you cant hep but think Mexico is Damed. There seems to be no order and the country is entirely corrupt. If i was a Mexican it would totally depress me. There are some very gruesome scenes of what happened to some of the Cartel members and their victims and it's not for the faint hearted but don't let that put you off what is a fascinating look into another world.
POWERFUL. Beautifully directed. Exciting, engaging, probably the best doc I've ever seen.

"Cartel Land" is one of the most compelling documentaries that explores organized crime between the Mexican-American border and how residents of both countries are trying to stop the spread of drugs and violence. Some of the raw video is shocking and disgusting and if anything, should spike the height of conversation going into the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election.

Two men stood against on the different side of the border for the same cause.I was not sure what to expect from this film. By seeing its poster, my mind was very clear that it definitely some serious subject. I'm kind of a person who's not okay with the lions killing a zebra on the animal planet, so I was worried about the clips they might show would be too violence. You know, in the movies everything's fake, and this isn't a movie, but a documentary. That's why I simply disliked 'The Act of Killing'.The opening scene was something like 'Breaking Bad', so I thought it might told from the bad guy's perspective about how their network and business would work. But everything drastically changed after the 5-10 minutes of the film. It's where the original story commence.The two main characters were introduced who are fighting for a same cause, but separated by the international line. Across the border, under the different society and government, how these two sacrifice their lives in battle against the dangerous networks that threatens the peace is the story.In a small town on the southern border of the US, a small paramilitary team headed by Tim has taken such a measure to prevent the all kinds of trafficking. In the same line, Dr. Mireles from the Michoacan, Mexico, goes a bit bigger and stronger by forming a force with the volunteered people with arms to fight for the same mission.The film had many the phases, not like the chapters or the episodes, but like a split in the narration to cover the other side of the story. The stories of two men and their undertaking was the prime focus. That's what I thought, you know I felt it was a modern day 'The Magnificent Seven', but in the larger scale of everything. Only until a twist that surprised me, because I was not thought a tale would turn like this."I believe what I'm doing is good.And I believe what I'm standing up against is evil."So what's the twist? I tell you, you know, one man was doing his task all by himself with the help of a few other buddies. On the other side, the man's contribution becomes the nation and international news and publicity. In such circumstance, a fame can turn the destiny of a man on whatever side. It's not like why he did what he had done, but a default human nature.I thought 'Heli' was a fictional work. After seeing this documentary I'm not sure how to judge any country by what they depict in their films. Every nation has its flaws, but I wondered why Mexican government was so blind over drug trafficking as shown in this film, if the information was correct. The absence of the federal law enforcement agencies on those disputed places is really a humiliation for the government after this film officially entered the Oscars race.I don't think taking action again them won't collapse the nation or the economy. And again, I'm not the right person here to analyse and predict the nation's fate. I've never been to Mexico and I know little about Mexico, but all this only because of the curious to know the truth, that's all. When it comes to the filmmaking, I don't know how it was made.Documentaries usually follows with the series of interviews and the recorded clips, in this it was a live shot like any entertainment film. Maybe I must look for director's Q&A for the answers. But something was sure, that production happened at the right place at the right time.This a very good documentary film, very gripping and interesting storyline with the characters. I don't watch documentaries on the regular basis and to be honest, I saw it for the Oscars nod, to know what its special. I don't think it is going to win, certainly I can't either rule out the chances as it made this far. Anything might happen, so wait and see.It had a few dull moments, lot like a pause in the narration or took a wrong diversion after the first half. But during the conclusion, brought back to the track and clarified many doubts, yet leave a few unanswered. Not for the sake of the Academy Awards nominee, you can give it a try if you feel you're interested to know why the people are taking arms in their hands to fight the evil force that corrupting our society.8/10

Perhaps the most educational of this year's nominated films. Takes a topic that in the US is not covered adequately by the main stream media and takes you into the center of the issue. Important film. CDW
A look at the people who are trying to do something about the drug cartels in Mexico. A very impressive story with some daring camerawork and a very sombre jolt back down to reality to end with.

Having liven in Arizona, in Tucson no less and spent times hunting in the Mountains South of Tucson, just 15 miles from the Mexico border, I can say the Mexican Drug cartels are causing major problem for the U.S. Cartel Land shows not just the problems on the US side but more importantly the problems in Mexico. It also talks a lot about the Mexico vigilantes and how they try to clean their towns. At the same time showing how the Autodefense (Mexican vigilantes) sometimes abuse this power. In all this film mostly shows how little power the Mexican Government has against the cartels and how that lack of control is causing problem for us hear in America. On a side note, if people just stopped doing so many drugs there wouldn't be this problem. Just saying.

A really strong documentary about the boarder issues that have been brought to more spotlight than usual this year for all the wrong reasons. This would serve as a good companion piece to Sicario that deals with similar issues. I think this will be in the line up on Oscar nominations morning
An interesting documentary on the war on drugs with the cartels -- one that exposes the corruption & never-ending fight that may never have an end.

The story of the Mexican vigilantes is engrossing and rich, with nuances that expose some of the complexities that exist with the cartel/vigilante/government struggle for power in these rural communities. The parallel that tries to be drawn with the Arizona civilian army is confusing, and at times seems contrived. While the coverage of the strife that happens in Michaoacan is insightful, the opposite is true for the coverage of the self armed, racist border patrol. It knocks you over the head, trying to juxtapose the stories of self determination in two communities that struggle against drug cartel violence. The movie could have had more direction and purpose if it hadn't included the Arizona vigilantes. While they do have a story to to tell, it doesn't add much to the narrative.
Very interesting documentary, very sad as well, but important to know. Definitely recommend watching.
I liked itShow that are no lines between the mexican covernment and the cartel.

Terrifying insight into one of Mexico's lawless rural provinces. The complex and intractable problems highlight the terrible burden carried by ordinary people in the unwinnable and senseless "war on drugs". Matthew Heineman?s cinematic and unflinching portrayal of vigilantes illustrates the corruptive nature of money and power in a culture where brutality knows no bounds.
A gripping tale of horror and violence inflicted upon the people of Mexico by the Drug cartels.

In the stunning Oscar-caliber documentary Cartel Land, director-cinematographer Matthew Heineman embeds himself in anti-drug vigilante groups north and south of the US-Mexico border, taking us right into the heart of the action. On the Arizona border US vet Tim Foley has formed a vigilante group out of frustration at flagrant lawlessness. In Michoacan, 1,000 miles south, where death is an everyday occurrence, Jose Mireles, a medical doctor leads the Autodefensas, intent on driving out the Knights Templar cartel. There are severed heads, dead bodies, a survivor's account of having to witness the unspeakable murder of her husband and other family members, interviews with workers in a meth lab, real shootouts. Dr. Mireles, a charismatic leader, nearly dies in a plane crash. Originally embraced by the local population, the vigilantes' lack of discipline is their undoing. Infiltrated by the cartels, they often behave no better than their enemy.

This is a corresponding documentary to "El Alcalde", about the group of Autodefensas in the state of Michoac�n, with it's background initial success in the fight against the cartels, criminals and the government forces, and the splitup into the "legal" Rural Forces, and its decline into corruption and new cartels. The parallel story of a small US civil autodefense group at the border in Arizona which admirers the Mexican Autodefensas is not so strong and could have been left out.You don't need to watch "Sicario", rather watch this and El Alcalde instead to get some background information.

Cuando un cineasta estadounidense intenta adentrarse en el mundo de las milicias provocadas por el narco, los cuidadores de la frontera en estados unidos y las fuerzas de autodefensa en michoacan, uno espera en contrar paralelismos, pero siempre resalta de manera directa el hecho de que el entorno de michoacan es de un abandono y de una desesperacion barbaros y abrumadores.No hay un solo elemento redimiente en la atuacion o falta de ella del gobierno y el ver de cerca el horrible efecto que tiene un cartel en todo un estado corrompiendo plenamente sus instituciones y actuando con increible sadismo contra la gente indfensa hace que aparentemente se justifique la aparicion de estos grupos.Mas cuando estos empiezan a cometer las atrocidades de las que acusan al contrario es cuandov es que el problema de fondo es super dificil de solucionar

The problem is that the lines are blurred as to who the criminals are and on what side they are on. Watching this film you cant hep but think Mexico is Damed. There seems to be no order and the country is entirely corrupt. If i was a Mexican it would totally depress me. There are some very gruesome scenes of what happened to some of the Cartel members and their victims and it's not for the faint hearted but don't let that put you off what is a fascinating look into another world.
POWERFUL. Beautifully directed. Exciting, engaging, probably the best doc I've ever seen.

Just brilliant. A real life hero captured on film.
multiple approach into the cartel problem with the intriguing mix of vigilante and corruption. But lack of even the hope or hint of resolution is unsatisfactory.
Gripping, engaging, disturbing, and rewarding, Catrtel Land is a well-balanced documentary with a crazy level of access to things you've never seen before regarding the cartel wars in Mexico.
Truth is more gripping than fiction

Mi primera pelicula dentro de la carrera por el Oscar 2016 y sin duda es una grata sorpresa.Un documental dificil de ver donde tenemos a un Mexico hundido en la delincuencia y un gobierno inutil que no hace nada. Del otro lado tenemos a la frontera con Arizona que esta controlada por el narcotrafico y como el gobierno de EU trata de recuperar su territorio.La camara sabe donde ir y que mostrar, el trabajo de Heineman es estupendo, un gran documental que vale la pena ver.

En cuanto al documental es un poco triste ver como el director malgasta tanto buen material en algo que parece m�s una cr�nica para noticiero amarillista. Las entrevistas que logr� son supremas pero no tuvo idea de como utilizarlas, l�stima. Triste ver como este fen�meno del paramilitarimo y/o autodefensas est� presente en todo el continente. Triste ver como la gente se pierde en la locura colectiva de la violencia, las armas, el poder, el dinero, las drogas. Triste ver como ese c�ncer avanza por todo M�xico y como acaba con su pueblo. Triste ver la cabalgante corrupci�n de los gobiernos. Pero lo m�s triste de todo es saber que en mi pa�s debemos estar mucho, pero mucho peor respecto a esto, que es mucho, mucho, pero mucho decir.
A truly inane bit of propaganda. The part that takes place in Mexico may be real but the idea that those knuckleheads are protecting our unprotected border from The Cartel is absurd.
started out cool but continued for way too long.
Wow. This movie will blow your mind and it should be required viewing for all adults and high school students in this nation. This movie presents a very balanced view of the current situation.

One of the reviews below calls this a "powerful documentary". I'm starting to think that nobody wants to be caught giving a bad review to a documentary, unless its about surfing or something safe to criticize. Personally, I might have enjoyed this more had I gone in knowing that I would learn exactly nothing about the subject matter. I wish I could trust reviews of documentaries more so I could avoid certain films that really seem designed for the casual netflix user.

I thought it was an amazing story but could have been told much better. Firstly I don't think the group on the American side were that interesting or analogous to the group on the Mexican side. The Mexican side were basically an effective operation to fight criminality both in the cartels and the government. The American guys seemed like a bunch of lost souls. I wasn't even quite sure what they thought they were achieving but all it seemed to be was capturing some dumb kids. So the story on the mexican side was much more fascinating but it was told in a quite a muddled way. For example the split in Autodefensas (which was a key point) seemed confusing, Basically it was a filmmaker so familiar with his subject matter than he often lingers on irrelevant details while failing to explain major points. The story of Autodefensas was amazing and can be summed up by "Beware that, when fighting monsters, you yourself do not become a monster... for when you gaze long into the abyss. The abyss gazes also into you."
Excellent documentary, going right along with shows such as Nachos and Cartel. Not for the faint of heart. It's hard to find an answer for Mexico and it's drug wars, and there is no obvious hero.
Amazing movie! Seriously blew me away.
I find it has a pace problem. For viewers outside Mexico it might seem appealing but not sure it is what the reviewers claim it to be.
I really want to check this out.

A must see, raw and eye opening documentary about the vigilante efforts on both sides of the Mexican border. On one side, you see the rapid rise and downfall of Dr. Jose Mireles, who founds the Autodefensas, a citizen uprising that opposes the all-powerful drug cartels and corrupt police forces in the Mexican state of Michocan. On the US side, you follow the a paramilitary group called the 'Arizona Border Recon' that patrols the Altar Valley of Arizona, also called, "Cocaine Alley". One of the better documentaries I've seen this year. If you love docus, this is a no-brainer.

Anyone who thinks the situation with ISIS or any of the wars in the Middle East require more attention from the U.S. than what is happening to the poor people of MEXICO needs to get educated by watching this insanely good documentary. It's haunting and a roller coaster ride of emotions based purely on fact- which in this case, is far more scary than fiction. Big Huge Thumbs Up!

We seem to focus on "south of the border" as the evil enemy when the true cartel engine are the millions of drug users in the USA. Cartels do what any corporation in the US would do - make a profit at ANY cost. Being incorporated legally does not equate to humanity in any sense - people, society, environment, sustainability of life. So... rather than billions on a fence, patrol, etc. why not put that money into drug treatment, enforcement in the US - or maybe just legalize everything and produce drugs for druggies for export. We already export products and ideas that are devastating and as long as money is made, taxes paid, then ...
If you're going to watch one documentary this year, make it this one!
An eye opening documentary regarding the very real war taking place south of the border.

Brilliant! Matthew Heineman is as fearless as he is talented. This is not only top notch unbiased journalism, but an unbelievable glimpse of what is going on in this turbulent part of the world. Heineman is literally on the front lines delivering a story that will blow your mind and keep you thinking about this spiraling crisis.

Up close and personal from all sides, Cartel Land paints an unvarnished bleak picture of just how badly corrupted all levels in Mexico are and the withering daily violence visited on rural villages as well as towns and cities. This documentary cannot have a happy ending, and it does not, as narco wars continue in much of Mexico. The true hero is a medical surgeon, Dr. Manual Miriles who suspends his medical work to devote his efforts to form a self defense group to fight the drug cartels, house by house if necessary. That Mexican police are corrupt is very clear, not so clear is how much corruption exists in Mexico's military. On camera gun battles are shown and the bravery of the camera crew is scary to watch but the results are gripping. Also well documented is the feckless of the federal government of the United States and its look the other way for the most part attitude. The film is presented mostly from the Mexican side, but also focuses on the Arizona Border Recon, a group of armed volunteers who scout the border for smugglers of both people and drugs. The film will leave you wanting to know more and the end coda is a sad one indeed for what happens to those who really care, yet get screwed by the Mexican federal government. Mexican President Nieto comes off looking like a narcisstic jackass.

Deep in the desert, where no legitimate government rules, a terrorist organization operates freely. Established governments fear them. They're well-financed, violent and ruthless. They control large swaths of land, including some cities and towns, causing local residents to live in fear. The members of this organization think nothing of murdering their enemies or killing just to make a point. They murder men, women and children, and even celebrate those deaths. They often decapitate their victims and sometimes use the internet to publicize videos and photos of their brutality. They even evoke the name of their god to justify their actions.I'm not talking about the Middle East or ISIS. I'm talking about Mexican drug cartels.The documentary "Cartel Land" (R, 1:38) shows everything I just described and more, but focuses mainly on vigilante groups who fight the cartels - on both sides of the U.S.-Mexican border. The film's title refers to areas of Mexico - and areas of the United States as well. U.S. Marine veteran Tim "Nailer" Foley leads a small paramilitary group called Arizona Border Recon whose volunteer members carry semi-automatic rifles and patrol Arizona's Altar Valley ("Cocaine Alley") for any sign of drug traffickers operating on the U.S. side of the border. Meanwhile, Jose Mireles leads the Autodefensas, whose members carry similar weapons in their quest to root out members of the ruthless drug cartel which operates in the area around the western Mexican state of Michoac�n. Both of these vigilante groups operate outside of their government's good graces but both governments refrain from direct action against the groups, even seeming to work with them on some level. The film alternates between following both groups as they struggle to turn back the advancing tide of cartels operating in their areas and also deal with manpower and leadership issues and with the friction between them and their respective governments. The story of these two vigilante groups is bookended by scenes shot during methamphetamine production by cartel affiliates at a remote outdoor location in Mexico. With their faces covered, this small group of men goes about their business unfettered and they even talk to the camera. At one point, their leader admits that what they're doing is wrong, but doesn't seem to care. He says that they'll continue cooking meth "as long as God allows it". Similarly, the leaders of both Arizona Border Recon and the Autodefensas justify their actions, even as some of their methods resemble those of the cartels. "Cartel Land" does things that I've never seen before in any documentary and does others better than I've ever seen them done. I've rarely praised either of these in other documentaries, but the cinematography and the score are both magnificent. Even more impressive than how it was shot is where it was shot. Besides gaining practically unprecedented access to that secret meth lab, director Matthew Heineman embeds with these vigilante groups, following them on their missions and getting up close and personal with some of the action in some obviously dangerous situations. (The film won the directing and cinematography awards in its category at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival.) The editing is also extremely impressive. The film contains more surprising reveals and vital story developments than in many traditional movie thrillers. Besides Heineman's obvious talents (and guts), it probably didn't hurt that one of the doc's executive producers is Kathryn Bigelow, Oscar-winning director of "The Hurt Locker" and "Zero Dark Thirty". Bigelow and Heineman's film is quite simply one of the best documentaries I have ever seen and only the second one that I have ever given this grade: "A".

Good documentary 3/5 - I didn't really feel like it shed any new light on the situation though. Previous documentaries that I've watched have revealed government officials and police partner with cartels. Cartels end up with everyone in their pocket - on their payroll and the Drug Machine just keeps on rolling. You realize that the poverty in Mexico has really forced most citizens hands into producing Meth and other substances. Putting yourself in their shoes - it's a hard to say that you would different given the options they have.
u'll be hurt at the end

This documentary illustrates the Catch-22ness of the situation. The U.S. helps the Mexican government, but their police and the so-called Mexican vigilantes originally fighting the cartel are now in bed with the cartel, so there's no way anyone can solve the drug "war" unless everyone in the U.S. puts their damn glass pipes down already. Yikes.
This is real movie making. Very well done. There are very few movies worth anything right now. This is the real deal. You felt like you were dropped into behind the scenes.
A stirring documentary about the war on drugs, that really get's into some forbidden territory.
Holy shit. This was pretty incredible. Hard to watch at times but amazing story.
My favorite doc from True/False. This doc has many layers & is quite eye opening about the cartels, government, & people of Mexico.
A movie that just presents some realities to us without giving us any inclination as to how this tragic situation can ever be resolved.
